results.title: Kick Drum Mayhem!
results.creator_credit: Adam Hunt, Zeyu Li, Darrin Verhagen and Shinjuku Thief
results.brief_description: The music in ‘Kick Drum Mayhem!’ was inspired by a Black Lung distorted kick drum and then given the Shinjuku Thief treatment with Korean percussion and Wagnerian brass. The end result is so overblown that it was felt that it could provide an interesting counterweight for the zany playfulness of Ivan Gaal’s ‘Applause Please’ from 1974. Freshly edited for the millennial attention span.

results.title: Shinjuku Thief Remixes
results.brief_description: Supported by the City of Melbourne COVID-19 arts grants, this project engaged composers, sound designers and video editors to experiment and remix ACMI archive footage. A bold piece of music inspires a conceptual pairing from the collection, the elements of which are then carefully assembled into a microstructural puzzle of tight gestural relationships.

results.title: Salsa Catastrophe
results.creator_credit: Zeyu Li, Darrin Verhagen and Shinjuku Thief
results.brief_description: The music in ‘Salsa Catastrophe’ was inspired by Cuban musical glee and paired with the 1958 film ‘The Car Stealers’ – an admonition from the Council of Fire and Accident underwriters about the inevitability of youthful idleness leading to crime. The smashup of those two seemingly unrelated components provides an initial provocation and relied on meticulously constructed audiovisual logic to knit them together.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Zeyu Li, Darrin Verhagen and Shinjuku Thief

results.title: Route 75
results.creator_credit: Zeyu Li, Darrin Verhagen and Shinjuku Thief
results.brief_description: This episode in the series revists some intense footage captured by Ivan Gaal (1975) at the Camberwell six-way intersection before lights were eventually installed. A remix by Shinjuku Thief of an Amnion noise track from the “Maelstrom” album propels us through the mayhem.

results.title: Dried Fruit Surprise
results.creator_credit: Sue Healey, Darrin Verhagen and Shinjuku Thief
results.brief_description: Shinjuku Thief’s latest playful tamper with the ACMI collection uses what might be the weirdest dried fruit advertising campaign ever directed by Fred Schepisi. Inverting the inherent misogyny of the original (see “A Hundred-Odd Years From Now” for how women from 2069 quickly become 1950s fumbling cake-baking housewives when they are newly-exposed to a cute bloke in their post-men environment), this new imagining of the narrative, in collaboration with choreographer and film maker Sue Healey, is as ‘Soylent Green’ as the revised colour grade. Alongside the edit and the tone set by the music, text from Daniel Schlusser, performed by Moira Finucane, help to reframe the original story into something not merely rich and strange, but ultimately somewhat tragic for poor raisinboy.

results.title: She's a woman: a media portrait
results.creator_credit: Sue Cram, Marianne Latham, Peter Beilby and Film House Tv
results.brief_description: This documentary deals with the issue of the way women are represented by the media, particularly television, whether it be in advertising, news items, drama series, quiz show hostess or contestant. Stereotype roles even carry down to children who feature in television advertising. However, it also covers the gradual breaking down of the traditional rules of sex roles including women in sport, women employed in male occupations, women becoming members in male dominated clubs and entering those hallowed domains which once used to be reserved for men only. Includes interviews with Bettina Arndt, Abigail, Dr Patricia Edgar, Phillip Adams, Patsy Adam Smith and others and contains advertising images, archival footage (including the Melbourne Cup fashion parades and Miss Australia Quest) and early newsreels. Although made in 1984, it is still very relevant and of great historical value. Narrated by Sigrid Thornton.

results.title: Shchors
results.creator_credit: Oleksandr Petrovych Dovzhenko and Kiev Film Studio
results.brief_description:
A depiction of the exploits of the Ukrainian civil war commander Nikolai Shchors (under whom director Dovzhenko served). The film opens during the 1918 German intervention in the civil war. Ukrainians partisans form a brigade known as the Boguns and join with the Tarashchansk regiment to oppose German and Rada forces. Thematically, the film is a heroic mission, a quest and biography of a civil war leader who was a Bolshevik icon. Stalin commissioned this film to be made and took a participatory role in the film’s production and direction. A protracted shoot proved taxing to Dovzhenko who was forced to submit every creative idea and episode for political approval. Despite its socialist-realist approach, the film contains poetic and memorable images typical of Dovzhenko’s style.

Credits: Director, writer, Alexander Dovzhenko ; photography, Y. Ekelchik ; music, Ukrainian State Symphony Orchestra.
Cast: Yevgeni Samoilov, Ivan Skuratov, N. Nikitina, L. Lyashenko.

results.title: Shinbone Alley
results.creator_credit: John Wilson, Preston M. Fleet and Fine Arts
results.brief_description: Adapted from the “Archy and Mehitabel stories” by Don Marquis with screenplay based on the musical book “Shinbone Alley” by Joe Darion and Mel Brooks, this wonderful animated feature brings with it all the atmosphere and style of its original broadway production, and much more. Its uniqueness is in the ink and paint animation technique blended with a jazzy musical comedy style and an eclectic mix of character personalities including Archy (Eddy Bracken), the philosophic newspaper journalist who after drowning himself comes back as a cockroach reincarnate; Mehitabel (Carol Channing) the sassy, indomitable and occasionally scandalous alley cat and friend of Archy’s; Big Bill (Allen Reed, Sr.) top cat and hell-bent on winning the affections of Mehitabel; and Tyrone T. Tattersall (John Carradine) the charming theatre cat who just loves to ham it up. Whimsical, weird, funny, sometimes dark, but with a fabulous music score by George Kleinsinger supported by the Fine Arts Hollywood Orchestra conducted by George Kleinsinger, the film is more directed at the older child or teenage/adult level. The voice characterisations are simply superb, and the support cast, which includes Hal Smith, Joan Gerber, Ken Sansom, Sel Delano and the Jackie Ward singers as the alley cats, are terrific. Also features Byron Kane as the narrator.

results.title: Sharking
results.creator_credit: Rod Rees, Terry Walker and Educational Media Centre, RMIT
results.brief_description: A history of the shark and of shark fishing and marketing in Australia. Shows the historical development of the Australian shark industry and the detailed research and managemnet of shark fishing resources being carried out byy the Victorian Fisheries and Wildlife Department.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rod Rees, Terry Walker and Educational Media Centre, RMIT

results.title: Shimmer in the city
results.creator_credit: Amanda Hickey and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.
